Award.AwardTitle: NRI: Collaborative Research: Accelerating Robotic Manipulation with Data-Enhanced Contact Mechanics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Robotic manipulation depends upon mechanical contact between robot and object. A better understanding of mechanical contact enables a wider range of more flexible manipulation techniques, which in turn enables the applications of greatest societal benefit such as eldercare, disaster response, or surgery. This project is developing a broader and more accurate understanding of frictional contact, using a fusion of physics and data. The project combines recent advances in a physics-based understanding of frictional contact with new machine learning techniques applied to a large corpus of experimental data. One operation of great interest is manipulation of an object held in the robot gripper, even when the gripper is very simple. Other operations of interest are handling objects in clutter, and manipulation of flexible objects, such as clothing.

The project is attacking several central challenges: modeling frictional contact, modeling deformation, measuring small motions and interaction forces, gathering large amounts of data, and developing techniques for learning in a closed-loop system. Parametric and semi-parametric models enable the project to apply engineering models enhanced with observation data, for both planning and control. New machine learning techniques such as predictive state representations (PSRs) enable identification and modeling of previously hidden state, as well as learning in closed-loop systems. New infrastructure enables gathering of relevant, precise data, on a large scale. The project is developing and employing a Robotic Manipulation Arena, with a unique combination of manipulation resources and instrumentation to provide high volumes of high quality experimental data. The primary outcomes are robust and practical contact models, so that robots can work more dexterously and opportunistically.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project goal was to establish the developing a better understanding of robotic manipulation through a fusion of physics and data. This includes explore use of data-driven parametric and semi-parametric models in planning and control and the development of algorithms for advanced autonomous robotic manipulation capabilities including manipulation of objects in cluttered spaces and under parameter uncertainty. 

A range of diverse problems were tackled including contact driven pushing and pulling, continuous time trajectory estimation for robotic planning and control, soft robotic modeling and control, generative modeling of perceptual models for manipulation, and learning robot manipulation skills from demonstration. Along the way new tools were developed including new inference methods for planning and control, new online learning perspectives on model predictive control and reinforcement learning, and a new class of motion generation algorithms based on Riemannian Motion Policies. In total, over 20 papers were produced as a result of this award. A paper by PhD student Ching-An Cheng that proved convergence criteria for a widely used class of imitation learning algorithms won the best paper award at a top artificial intelligence conference, a paper by PhD student Nolan Wagener that developed a new online learning perspective on control algorithms won best student paper at a top robotics conference, and a paper that developed new inference-based techniques for motion planning by PhD student Mustafa Mukadam received the Paper of the Year award from a top robotics Journal.

The impact of this work is quite broad.  Some of the results have already been taken up in course curricula and some have already found their way into industrial applications. The project also provided professional training and support for several students, including underrepresented minorities.


Last Modified: 07/23/2020
Modified by: Byron Boots
